Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Thermal Runaway and Pressure Suppression (TRAPS) for Lithium-Ion Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) or STTR Phase I project is to develop and commercialize a technology to mitigate safety concerns associated with lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery technologies in electric vehicle, transportation, and energy storage applications. Li-ion battery technology is one of the most transformative innovations in the past decade and continues to provide a platform for future technology development. The potential market size for Li-ion battery technology is substantial. Fueled by growth in energy storage and electric vehicle industries the Li-ion battery market is expected to grow to over US$100 billion by 2025. Adoption of Li-ion battery technology in the energy storage market being impeding by safety concerns, namely fire and explosion hazards. The technology to be developed in this Phase I project has the potential to be a low-cost, passive solution to mitigate these hazards, and alleviate these concerns. The technology has potential to have high market penetration in energy storage and transportation industries, and will enable adoption of transformative technologies that pushes us toward a greener and more sustainable energy future.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will explore and develop technology for passive mitigation of Li-ion battery fire and explosion hazards. For large multi-cell battery systems in energy storage, vehicle applications and among others, these hazards can damage nearby infrastructure and cause injury or death. Li-ion batteries can undergo a self-heating failure called thermal runaway that releases flammable gases. Thermal runaway poses significant challenges for available fire and explosion suppression systems because the gas release can continue unabated despite suppression of the incipient fire. Current mitigation approaches treat the consequences of the fire and do not address the root cause of the hazard, namely the production of flammable gases. The approach here is to develop technology to mitigate the root cause of the hazard and reduce the flammability of the battery gases. There is a clear need to increase the scientific understanding of passive mitigation mechanisms of hazardous and flammable gases in the thermal runaway environment. The overall objective of this project is to further the scientific understanding of these passive mitigation techniques and demonstrating proof-of-concept performance for Li-ion battery applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Under certain scenarios, Li-ion batteries can fail resulting in an exothermic release of flammable and toxic gases. For large multi-cell battery systems in energy storage, vehicle applications and among others the risk of thermal runaway can result in catastrophic fires, explosions and toxic gas release that can damage nearby infrastructure and cause injury or death. During thermal runaway, a high temperature, multi-species gas containing both flammable and toxic species is released at a high rate. Thermal runaway poses significant challenges for available fire suppression systems because the gas release can continue despite suppression of the incipient fire. In this STTR Phase I project, feasibility of a passive mitigation technology to address Li-ion battery fire, explosion and toxicity hazards was explored. Prior to this STTR Phase I Project, the physio-chemical approaches to mitigating gases released by Li-ion batteries during failure had not been previously validated. The experiment results obtained for physio-chemical materials are the first of its kind. A methodology and facility to evaluate material scale up was also developed, which provides a foundation for future material research. Development of a scale-up reactor facility was one of the key achievements of the Phase I  project. The experimental facility provides key infrastructure to simulate battery gas release and allows further exploration of novel materials. 

Broader/Commercial Impact

Li-ion battery technology is one of the most transformative innovations since first commercialized in the mid 1990s and continues to provide a platform for future technology development. The potential market size for Li-ion battery technology is substantial. Fueled by growth in energy storage and electric vehicle industries the Li-ion battery market is expected to grow to a nearly $600 billion industry by 2025. Several advances such as smartphones, wearable devices, and electric vehicles are all possible because of mobile energy supplied by high energy dense Li-ion batteries. Future viability of emerging technologies such microgrids, smart electrical grids, urban transportation solutions, self-driving cars and the internet of things are dependent on Li-ion battery technology. However, Li-ion battery safety concerns are impeding widespread adoption of these technologies. While generally safe, Li-ion batteries can catastrophically fail posing thermal hazards, including fires and explosions  that increase the risk to infrastructure and people. Robust safety systems, which often have significant weight and cost penalties, are required to reduce or eliminate these hazards. Several industry stakeholders including battery manufacturers, grid utilities, and automakers are positioned to benefit from mitigation strategies that can be either a stand-alone or integrated system in their end product. The mitigation concept proposed here has the potential to be a low cost, passive solution for these industries, and has potential for high commercial payback as the Li-ion battery market continues to grow and develop. TRAPS also has the potential to be integrated into fire fighting technologies to help the fire service suppress and mitigate Li-ion battery fire incidents. Furthermore, by alleviating Li-ion battery safety concerns, TRAPS has the potential to provide significant societal benefits by removing obstacles for adoption of transformative technologies. Because TRAPS addresses the source of battery fires and explosions, it has the potential to impact a broad range of industry segments including electric vehicles, e-mobility, and aerospace. The military, in particular, also faces similar challenges on board ships, aircraft, vehicles and other platforms where Li-ion batteries are being used. Additionally, Li-ion battery safety is a concern throughout the entire battery life-cycle including transportation, warehousing and recycling. TRAPS has the potential to be integrated into safety systems for handling Li-ion battery life-cycle logistics within the next decade.

 A key outcome from the Phase project includes improving the fundamental understanding of battery hazards, which helped address key knowledge gaps in the overall battery safety research community.  However, increasing the scientific understanding of Li-ion battery safety hazards not only supports Altect?s product development, but also provides public safety benefits within the next 2-3 years. The fire service is increasingly encountering Li-ion battery fires in the field while conducting infrastructure permitting activities or responding to emergency fire incidents. Fundamental research conducted through the Phase I project immediately provides the fires service with educational resources to increase their understanding of Li-ion battery fires, so that they can develop effective permitting and emergency response protocols to better serve and protect the public.
